A major epidemic of influenza‐like disease followed Carolman’s (Charlemagne’s) army across Europe in 876–877, having first arrived in Italy to spread northward, a directional pattern that was documented repeatedly for certain influenza pandemics occurring between 1510 and 1761, and also killing dogs and birds.

45 ] again first struck Italy and spread northward to affect the whole European continent, and again caused illness and death in humans, dogs, and birds.

32 Scholars have speculated that this was the first recorded pandemic of influenza, a possibility consistent with its appearance in southern Europe and its rapid spread northward.
